title: Introducing: Memory Fossils
content:
‘I want to live in lou reed’s unkempt hair’ states Memory Fossils on his bandcamp page.

A fairly understandable if not slightly bizarre sentiment if I’m being perfectly honest. There’s not quite the slickness nor the art rock vibe that Reed manages to instill, however Memory Fossils debut release entitled Brumous Boys is an accomplished collection of lo-fi gems. On Anatomies At Night is as twee and desirably honest sounding as anything Real Estate have ever written, never mind being insanely catchy.

Elsewhere on the release there’s the delightful drawl of Albert Camus, What Do You Do When I’m Not Around? and the fuzz drained hum of Lou Reed’s Tiny Echoes, sounding like a major label big budget artist attempting to record an album that sounds more modest than the financial backing would suggest. Nine tracks in total, most coming in at under two minutes, you know what you’re getting with Memory Fossils, gritty, slightly downtrodden sounding declarations of love, hate and disillusionment, and boy, isn’t it just brilliant?

Check out a couple of tracks within this article, and head over to the Memory Fossils bandcamp to grab the full release.
